acc_desc: Inflatable slide tipped over while 7-9 patrons on top of it. The slide fell on a man standing next to it, causing several fractures to his back, and minor injuries to several children. The accident was caused by allowing too many patrons on the device and operating it in an usafe manner.  The insurance company had solicited volunteers from their employees to staff the device in return for free tickets to the ball game.
injury_desc: The man who was crushed by the device died 9 days later of complications from his injuries. 2 children were transported to the ER, and 6 children were treated at the scene.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Two adult males were standing next to an inflatable slide when it tipped over on top of them.  One man suffered a fractured vertebrae and died later from complications. The other sustained head and back injuries.  Six children who were on the slide sustained minor injuries.  The investigation revealed the slide tipped over because there were too many children on one side and the slide was not properly anchored.  Volunteers were acting as attendants for the amusement device.  There were 7-9 children on the slide when it fell over.
injury_desc: 1 - death from pulmonary embolism caused by blunt force trauma; 1 - head and back injuries; 6 children had cuts, bruises, back and ear pain.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

source: California Division of Occupational Safety and Health

source: California Division of Occupational Safety and Health

source: Colorado Division of Oil and Public Safety
acc_desc: Two patrons climbed to the top of the wall, counted to three and jumped of the wall in unison. The auto-belay failed for one patron.

source: Wisconsin Dept. of Commerce, Safety and Building Division
acc_desc: Rider was released by the ride operator before the net was raised and airbag inflated, causing her to freefall 100 feet to the ground. According to a criminal complaint, the operator at the top of the ride was supposed to watch for an all-clear signal from the operator at the bottom who inflates the air bag that catches patrons more than 100 feet below. Investigators say the airbag meant to catch Marti was not inflated yet, and that the cage at the top of the ride was stopped before it reached the top. Carnell told investigators he didn't look for a signal at the bottom of the ride before he let Marti loose. He told investigators he "totally blanked."
injury_desc: Med-flighted to hospital: skull fracture; multiple severe fractures to back and pelvise; lacerated spleen, liver, intestines

acc_desc: The ride stopped due to motor trouble. Ride was evacuated by fire department with a couple of high reaches. Evacuation took 2.5 hours.
injury_desc: One patron complained of back pain. EMTs determined back pain was due to sitting on the ride for 2.5 hours.

source: Colorado Division of Oil and Public Safety
acc_desc: A train layover was caused by approaching a curve at a high speed, 12-17 miles per hour. Normal train speeds are 3-4 miles per hour.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: 14yo boy was injured during a walking water ball ride at the state fair. Upon entering the ride and beginning to walk, he lost his balance and fell on his right shoulder, tearing a ligament and breaking his collarbone near the joint. The victim 5'11", 240lbs. Due to his size/weight, occasionally his feet would make contact with the ground rather than floating on the water surface.
injury_desc: Dislocated shoulder, broken clavicle near AC joint, and torn ligament requiring surgery and extensive PT.
category: Impact: hit something in participatory attraction

Patron was strapped in by an employee. About 90 seconds into the ride, the patron flipped over going upside down and slid partway out of the harness. His legs were still in the harness, then he fell about 5.5 feet to the trampoline below. The patron was slight of build, but harnesses were provided based on patron's age, not size. The patron sought medical care as a precaution, and was released with instructions to rest.  The patron raised concerns that there was only a 5' x 5' trampoline under the bungee ride with hardwood floor surrounding.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Two girls were playing in a rented inflatable device at a neighbor's birthday party. High winds pulled the ride up from the ground and blew it over a wall. The 11yo got out of the device when it landed in another yard. Winds picked it up again and it struck the roof of a house. The second girl fell out of the device onto the roof. The inflatable then took off again and finally crashed into a 2-storey house. The inflatable was staked into rocky ground. Stakes were described as looking like large nails with a small head, 12 inches long and 5/8" diameter. The stakes were not hammered all the way into the ground, with about 4" of top exposed. At the time of the party, the area was experiencing wind gusts exceeding 35mph. Arizona does not regulate the safety of inflatables. CPSC talked with the owner/operator who said his company doesn't have a copy of the owner's manual for the device, but that inflatables are easy to set up and operate. He said that the 25' inflatable has six sides and they used 4 stakes (12" by 5/8") to anchor it. Winds were approx. 12mph when his people set up the device.
injury_desc: 9yo and 11yo girls suffered scrapes and bruises. 9yo had a concussion and was hospitalized overnight.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

acc_desc: Miniature train derailed and crashed into a ravine. The operator admitted he was driving too fast.  A state inspector admitted he had falsified an inspection report prior to the accident. According to a news article: The crash led to changes in inspections, as well as a law requiring that miniature trains have working speedometers and devices that limit speed. No criminal charges were ever filed, though an inspector and the train’s operator were fired.
injury_desc: 6yo boy was killed and 28 others were injured, some critically.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: 47yo male (69.5" tall, 174lbs) was ejected sideways from his carrier as the vehicle made a sharp turn.  He fell to the ground, hitting a by-stander as he landed.  Investigators talked with 7 people who had previously reported, to the carnival company, incidents on the same ride where the restraint bar released while the ride was in progress, including several who were riding in the the same car as the deceased. Texas does not have a regulatory unit to investigate accidents. The carnival company conducted its own investigation, which found the ride to be safe.  CPSC inspected the coaster two months after the accident, after it had been dismantled and moved to another state. During that inspection, the lap bars worked as they are supposed to.
injury_desc: (1) death from blunt trauma injuries; (2) sprained or broken foot, laceration to knee

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Two children, 8 and 9yo, were injured when a dust devil or sudden updraft of wind lifted an inflated jumping castle airborne with 2 children inside and blew it across three lanes of traffic before landing on the median. Owner/operator set up the device and left it in the care of the cultural center, with instructions to deflate it if winds exceeded 25 mph. The owner/operator did not have a manual for the device, but claimed he pounded in 18" stakes using a sledgehammer into hard-packed dirt.  Police found no negligence and attributed the incident to an uncontrollabe weather event.
injury_desc: Lacerations to head and face, treated and released at local hospital

acc_desc: Father and toddler son were riding in a double seat kart. Their kart rear-ended another kart, causing his son to hit his head on the steering wheel. The father had asked the operator to adjust the steering wheel position when they loaded, but the attendant did not know it could be adjusted.  State inspector was unable to obtain the height of the toddler (minimum height for ride is 36").  "It is unclear if the son was tall enough, the seat belts were tight enough or the steering wheel was too close to him." He ordered that owner/operator to retrain the attendants on all restraints and adjustability of steering wheel.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Four females ranging in age from 2 to 6 sustained head and leg injuries when they fell to the ground from an unknown height after the (rental) inflatable slide attraction they were on overturned in a gust of wind. Most details were unavailable. It is unknown whether/how the device was anchored, whether any adults were supervising, whether the rental company had proper training, etc. Several metal stakes measuring 18-24" were found on the scene, as well as two small sandbags, but it is unknown whether the device was anchored per manufacturer's instructions.  According to the weather service, wind speed at the time of the incident was approximately 21mph with gusts of 40-48mph
injury_desc: Head and leg injuries, 4 children transported to the hospital
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

Rental customer reported that a 10yo boy was jumping in the bounce house and his teeth were caught on the inside of the basketball hoop, and were pulled out of his mouth. Person acting as attendant stated that there were 5 children on the device. They were sliding down the slide, one at a time; when they got to the bottom of the slide, they would jump to the basketball hoop.  The injured child jumped to the hoop and then bounced again. His head went up into the net. He was hanging by his neck for a split second, then slipped through to his teeth.  He was hanging by his teeth for about 15 seconds before he got loose and fell.  The mother says her son has been having nightmares since the event.  She feels the net should be removed.
injury_desc: Lost teeth and broken pallet bone. Treated at the hospital with follow-up dental work. Mouth wired shut, unable to eat solid food for 1 month.

Six children suffered minor injuries from flying debris (stroller, ice chests and part of the air compressor).

Adult patron suffered a broken neck while using the inflatable device. He was racing a friend and climbed the first wall, then went head first over the top, striking his head on the squeeze feature below and hyper-extending his head and neck backwards. He immediately lost feeling in his extremities and knew what had had happened. The injured patron is a doctor and several of the party-participants were doctors. According to the operator, the children were required to watch the safety video, but the adults stood outside the video room. The accident was reported to regulators by the injured patron several months after the incident.

Ride failed causing 3 patrons to become stuck 30 feet off the ground. A drive chain came off its sprocket and wedged itself between two drive gears. The fire department was called to assist in the rescue. Investigators found that the drive sprocket on the motor had hairline cracks in 5 of 11 teeth with one tooth broken axially in half, and another sprocket suffered damage from the chain wearing against the side of it.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: 3 rented inflatable bouncers and slides came loose from their anchors, injuring 13 people at a soccer match. Weather was clear and mild with winds 9-29 mph. Highest winds were reported from 2-4pm when gusts reached nearly 30mph. At approximately 3pm, the 3 inflatables broke free of their anchors and began blowing across the fields. At least one bouncer had children still inside. An inflatable slide was over 10 feet in the air at one point. The bouncers measured as large as 20' long, 17' wide and 16' high.
injury_desc: 13 people were injured, mostly children with minor abrasions and contusions. Some were inside an inflatable; some were outside and struck by the units as they blew away. The most serious injury was sustained by a 36yo female who was using the school track when she was struck by an inflatable. She sustained serious head and spinal injuries requiring hospitalization.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Three patrons (ages 9, 20, 35) were injured when a light fixture on the ride suddenly detached as the ride was spinning. The interior connection of the light fixture to the center tower bent, but stayed connected. This allowed the other end of the light fixture to fall down into the path of the moving passenger cars. The ride was moving at full speed when the light detached. The operator manually moved the ride time dial to off, which cut the power and allowed the ride to start slowing down on its own. She told police she did not activate the emergency brake because she didn't know what that lever was. As the ride slowed, two carnival employees jumped the fence to help patrons, but became victims of the accident. One (20yo male) was struck by one of the ride's passenger cars and thrown to the ground. Another (35yo male) attempted to jump on the ride and manually grab the ligh fixture. As he neared the swinging light, he was pulled or knocked down to the ground. Utah does not regulate the safety of amusement rides, so the ride's inspection and maintenance history are unknown.
injury_desc: (1) hit by ride, no further information; (2) bruising and scrapes to most of right side of body, 3" long laceration to right bicep; (3) laceration to head and ear requiring stitches

acc_desc: Patron stated he was sitting on his seat when the Monorail tire blew and he put all of his weight on his right thumb.

Inflatable slide was set up at a Country Club event on a tennis court per customer request with sandbags to secure the unit.  The owner/operator left the device without an operator in attendance. The customer assumed control over the device.  At some point, parents complained that the couldn't see their kids on the device and asked staff members to move it 150'.  The staff members did not of the sandbags were attached to the unit. No one from the Country Club was supervising use of the device or in proximity to the device. The inflatable tipped over with 6-8 kids at the top and 20 more climbing up the ladder.  Country Club staff righted the device and continued to use it, but did report the incident to the owner/operator who notified state authorities. The inspector ordered the customer to shut down the device, then drove to the Country Club to inspect. The blower was barely operating because 3 separate extension cords had been linked together to run the blower after it was moved 150' from the GFCI outlet.  Country Club staff reported that none of the kids had been injured when the device tipped over.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

source: Michigan Dept. of Labor and Economic Growth
acc_desc: Train was making its run around the park when the first car behind the engine and tender came off the track and was stopped shortly after when the operator realized a derailment had occurred. The wheel sets became dislodged from their normal location and without the support from the wheel sets underneath, the red car flipped on its right side (slowly with a fairly gentle impact). 12 people were riding, approxmately half adults and half children. No injuries were reported. Stone on track or in flangeway may have caused derailment or possibly a combination of a shift in the load in the car in association with current set-up of stabilizing rollers.

source: West Virginia Division of Labor, Safety Section
acc_desc: Sweep broke at the hinge pin weldment, causing it to fall and hit the ground while in operation. The sweep had 2 tubs on the end: one empty and one with 2 patrons. The park had records showing annual NDT was performed with "no relevant indications found" four months prior to the accident.  The investigating officer did find visual evidence of prior cracking on sweeps. The park decided to dismantle the ride instead of repairing it.

It appears the device was unattended. The closest operator was attending the device next to the obstacle course. Coroner could not determine what caused the death, but noted cardiac indications that could neither be ruled in or out as cause of death.

She was moved out of the water and onto a backboard at the edge fo the pool. The lifeguard noticed she was not breathing and began rescue breathing, which revived the patron.

Patron said she was riding with 3 grandchildren when her raft went past the unload area and stopped at the bottom of the lift. Patron's raft started to dip under the water on the side her grandchildren were riding. Patron unbuckled her restraint to help her grandchildren when the lift started and a raft came out of the water. When the raft went up the lift, a second raft hit her raft. Owner/operator determined that the patron's raft slipped through the bottom brake. The air line was repaired.

Operator loaded 16 kids onto the ride and walked around checking the seatbelts.  When he started the ride, he did not notice the 3yo boy had climbed off his carrier and was in between the motorcycle and the tarp that covered the sweeps.  He said his position at the time was in a blind spot behind the center pole of the ride.  As he turned the ride on, he heard someone say 'there's a kid loose'.  The operator was unable to stop the ride before a sweep hit the child and a jeep ran over the boy's leg. The operator stated that the seatbelt was still latched on the vehicle the boy had been riding. State regulators recommended the following: (1) operators be trained to verbally instruct toddler to stay seated at all times; (2) operators be trained to visually check all carriers before starting the ride; (3) owner should install a convex mirror to assure that the operator can see all patrons from the operator station at all times.
injury_desc: Bump on the head with scrapes and bruises to leg. Treated and released from the hospital.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Child was attending a party and boarded a coin-operated hamster wheel ride at a restaurant. She had removed her shoes and was wearing socks. The child was running in the ball and tried to slow down. An older boy entered the ride and caused the victim to fall down. According to reports, the ride was not being supervised by employees and there is no way to quickly slow down or stop the ball from rotating. CPSC talked with the service technician about the ride. He said it takes at least 45 lbs of force for the wheel to rotate freely. The ride is not for toddlers, but usually can be used by children 5 and up depending on their size. There are no height, age or weight restrictions posted next to the ride.
injury_desc: Teeth knocked out, lacerations to lips and tongue

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: An unattended 4yo (40" tall, 35lbs) was slightly injured when she became entrapped in an indoor inflatable obstacle course at an entertainment center. The child fell in the gap (52-53" high) between the interior walls of the two-piece inflatable unit. She became completely enclosed, compressed between the two inflated walls and unable to move. The mother heard her daughter's screams and, with help from another mother, they pulled her out of the gap. The safety label on the inflatable states that patrons must be at least 48" tall, 8 inches taller than the child who was entrapped. Investigators found that the FEC's president and shift manager were aware of this particular entrapment hazard; it had occurred on the same unit a few times without reported injuries. The company's hazard mitigation consists of (1) a procedure to instruct patrons and supervising parents: "do not climb on or over the walls"; (2) a waiver that must be signed by supervising adults stating that they will comply with all rules, warnings, etc.
injury_desc: Minor abrasions, difficultly breathing while entrapped

acc_desc: While repeling on the rock wall #1, her pant leg caught in a handhold and she began to twist upside down. She was caught from being all the way by a friend's father when she was at a 130" turn.

acc_desc: 3yo girl fell from over 7 feet when she slipped from the double restraint on the ride (she was strapped into a seatbelt and had a lap bar over her). The girl met the 42" height requirement. The child's mother was planning to ride with her and her twin brother, but the lapbar would not lock across her legs due to her size. She asked her 8yo nephew to accompany the children. The 8yo was sitting on the inside with the 3yo girl to the outside. Mother stated this was the first year the twins were tall enough to ride the bigger rides. CPSC examined the ride and the dimensionality of the seating area and restraints, but did not present a conclusion. The ride was operating as intended by the manufacturer.
injury_desc: Patron lost consciousness, was transported to the hospital for CT, MRI and x-rays, and diagnosed with concussion.

acc_desc: Patron became trapped between two inflatables, which are part of the same obstacle course. The room had black lights and loud music and parent did not have eyes on child for several minutes. The device is a 3-part inflatable unit with a slide in the middle and is designed for children. It was assembled per manufacturer's recommendation, anchored to the I-bolts in the floor . Neither loud music or use of blacklights is a violation of state code, but the owner/operator said he would discontinue blacklight operations and turn music volume down.

acc_desc: Patorn stated the attendant pressed the lap bar onto his previously injured left knee as he was being seated. After riding, his knee was too painful to bear weight.

2yo slid out of the ride after it made 3-4 rotations. Child fell head-first and landed on the metal deck below.  Uncle states the child was strapped in prior to starting the ride and that the operator verified this. The car was approximately 5 feet off the ground when the boy' head and torso slid underneath the security bar. The vehicle spun a few times until the child fell out. State investigators found that the 2yo met the height limit for children riding alone, and concluded that the injuries resulted from "the rider's inability to comply with responsibilities assumed by the rider". He was 2 years and 14 days old.
injury_desc: Injuries to forehead and mouth. Transported to Children's Hospital.

3yo riding unaccompanied was loaded into the coaster and seatbelt was latched.  Witnesses state he became agitated, unlatched his seatbelt and got out of his seat. He attempted to hold onto the side of the coaster, but was ejected as the car rounded a corner.  There is no way for the operator to stop this ride while it is in motion (gravity coaster). The ride had been modified with seatbelts per NY state regulations imposed after a child was ejected from a Wacky Worm in that state. CT investigators found that the carnival height limit sign incorrectly stated that children 36" or taller could ride alone.  The manufacturer's manual states that children 36-42" tall must ride with a supervising companion.  The child ejected in this accident was 38" tall.
injury_desc: Fractured skull, laceration to head, admitted to hospital

source: California Division of Occupational Safety and Health

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: 3yo male (41" tall) riding a gravity fed children's coaster by himself slipped underneath both a metal lap bar original to the ride and retrofitted seat belt installed on the seat. He either jumped or fell from the car from a height of 18"-24" while it was in motion. The child struck his head and face on a metal support structure of the ride before hitting the asphalt on which the ride was situated.  The victim met the minimum height requirement posted at the ride entrance.  CPSC investigators could not confirm whether the ride had an emergency stop mechanism. State investigators found no sign of ride malfunction and the ride was cleared.
injury_desc: Skull fracture and multiple lacerations requiring stitches. Hospitalized for 4 days.

acc_desc: In preparation for an approaching storm, the sky ride was put into stand-by mode. This procexss allows those who are on the ride to complete and finish their ride normally, while prohibiting additional riders from boarding the ride. Once the ride is complete and all passengers have exited, the service car is parked in the south station and the ride is turned off. With only 4 chairs still containing passengers, the entire town lost power. Maintenance was notified to begin the evacuation procedure.

Operator said she didn't see anything happen, but there was a small child who was crying after coming out of the ride. She went into the device, then the child yelled and he immediately exited the ride. The operator will be retrained.

source: California Division of Occupational Safety and Health
acc_desc: Evacuation involving 15 patrons who were suspended 300 feet in the air for 3 hours while the park maintenance department attempted to identify the problem and return ride to home position. Cause was an improperly adjusted cable tension, allowing the hub to become unleveled and causing wear to a slipper shoe and safety brake housing. This wear resulted in a safety brake deployment, which prevented the ride from descending properly to its home position. State regulators learned about the incident through a media report.

acc_desc: Evacuation involving 20 patrons who were suspended 300 feet in the air for 3.5 hours while the park maintenance department attempted to identify the problem and return ride to home position. Similar to previous incident on this ride 12 days prior. Cause was an improperly adjusted cable tension, allowing the hub to become unleveled and causing wear to a slipper shoe and safety brake housing. This wear resulted in a safety brake deployment, which prevented the ride from descending properly to its home position. State regulators learned about the incident through a media report.

acc_desc: One of the ride's 4 outriggers had been removed by the ride operator and wood blocking was used instead. The ride was opened to the public at noon in this condition. While operating, the forces of the ride broke the wood blocking apart and caused a portion of the ride to hit the deck and spew decking and ramps around the area of the ride. A manual evacuation was performed to unload passengers. One patron's shoulder was hit by the platform; another patron was hit in the back of the legs by the gates.

State regulators issued an Order Prohibiting Use along with six requirements: one pertained to removing unauthorized modification to passenger units; three pertained to operational requirements; one pertained to the control of hazardous stored energy and lack of acceptable fall protection procedures or equipment.

acc_desc: Several inflatables were set up for a school event. All were secured to the ground. Winds were approximately 15 mph with gusts in the 20's. A whirlwind came into the area and picked up the Rat Race 20 feet into the air and flipped it over a bounce house, landing 30-40 yards from where it was.  Students were on the device when it became airborne and were thrown to the ground. 7 were taken to the hospital: 5 injured in the Rat Race, 1 injured earlier in another inflatable, and 1 injured in the grandstand. The inflatables had not been inspected per state law prior to operation.
injury_desc: Two children were hospitalized overnight, five were treated and released.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

acc_desc: During a normal cycle of the ride, it became stuck in the raised position. All patrons were evacuated by the Fire Department. One of the brake cams was not adjusted properly and engaged when the attraction was cycling with an unbalanced load. Owner/operator was required to retrain maintenance employees and update maintenance program to include additional inspection points.
Patrons father called several days later to report that his son had bumped his head on the car as it was coming into the station.
category: Impact: hit something within ride vehicle

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: One of the trucks containing 3 child patrons tipped over forward into the truck in front of it while in motion. A 5yo boy riding in the back seat was ejected from the truck and was dragged around the circumference of the ride until the operator was able to engage the emergency stop. Two other children were not ejected, but suffered minor injuries. Investigators found that a hitch ball connecting the truck to the ride's center spoke had become dislodged from the socket which it was supposed to be connected to.
injury_desc: 5yo boy suffered a head laceration requiring 16 staples and an unknown number of sutures plus cuts, scrapes, buises, and was hospitalized overnight. 4yo boy and 8yo girl in the same truck suffered minor injuries.

acc_desc: The truck flipped over onto the one in front of it. Child had a laceration on the forehead and transported to the hospital.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Ride malfunctioned causing a 16yo girl fell 20 feet to the ground. Patron was transported to the hospital and life-flighted to a Denver Children's Hospital due to severe head trauma.  Likely cause is that an R key holding the pulley's two sides in place had come out, causing the bungee to detach. NOTE: This ride was involved in another serious accident a year later (7/18/14) where a 16yo suffered multiple skull fractures after a fall caused by a broken cable. The CPSC report on that accident included an insurance inspection report describing poor maintenance of the rides by this carnival company.
injury_desc: Multiple skull fractures, ruptured ear lobe.

acc_desc: Bump from another go cart

Patron was in moonwalk for 5 min. Nearing the end of the time segment, he asked to come out, then complained about a sore left wrist. He claimed another patron fell on his wrist while he was lying on the floor of the moonwalk. Ride operator did not see incident, even though this product has clear vinyl sides all around.

source: West Virginia Division of Labor, Safety Section
acc_desc: Adult patron (renter) who had been drinking was using a rental inflatable slide at a party. She caught her foot in the slide material and fractured her ankle.  Investigators found deficiencies in operational policy (no documented training or training manuals), but that appeared to be unrelated to the injury. After a thorough investigation of the device, the state determined that the slide cover (a replacement of the original) was not propoerly fitted to the unit and created extra material in front of the slider. The manufacturer was not identified in the report, but was headquartered in China.

source: California Division of Occupational Safety and Health
acc_desc: Patron called two days later to report that she could not get the overhead restraints to lock when she rode the ride. She stated she is overweight. The ride operator came over and tried to push the restraint down, but it wouldn't lock. The operator then told her they had a seat that would accomodate her, but she would have to wait for the next ride cycle. She waited and was seated in another seat. The restraint locked and she rode with no issues. She felt fine after the ride, but noticed a large bruise on her shoulder the following day.
category: Load/Unload: hit or pinched by restraint

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Attraction consists of a scaffold tower platform placed next to an inflatable impact attenuation device (air bag) with a freefall of 27 feet. Patron did not follow instructions for jumping off the platform onto the air bag. Instead of jumping forward and extending his feet an landing on his back or buttocks, he attemped a double front flip, somersaulting forward in a tuck position.  He failed to come out of his tuck and landed on his neck. Ride owner/operator told CPSC of three other injuries on this device during the Country Fest: 2 fractured ankles and a back injury.

acc_desc: According to witness statements gathered by police, the victim was operating a go kart down an incline and through a curve when he struck the barrier wall, lost control, causing the go kart to flip onto its side. Statements indicated that the victim was traveling at a very fast rate of speed, but no faster than any other go kart operator on the track at the time. After striking the barrier wall the go kart began to skid sideways and flipped onto its side. The head rest area of the go kart crossed over the barrier guard and the victim struck his head on a wood post which holds the barrier guards in place. Inspectors noted no obvious defects with the go kart or safety restraints, and brakes seemed to be properly functioning. Inspectors saw no defects with the design of the track.
category: Collision: go-kart or bumper car hit stationary object

acc_desc: The report did not describe the incident, but it said that all 4 people on the tube were seated properly, weighed prior to getting on the tube, and the tube was not overweight. The safety light system used to signal when a tube has cleared the ride was working properly. The patron height measuring stick was found to be only 47" off the floor, yet the minimum height requirement is 48". The park said that was ok because patrons were being measured without shoes and they had documentation that this was acceptable. The state investigator required the park to return the height measurement device to 48" above the floor.

acc_desc: Six children suffered minor injuries when a rented inflatable slide tipped over while 8-10 children were on it, causing the children to fall to the ground. Many children were bunched at the top and moved to one side, unbalancing the device. The slide was placed on grass and secured with stakes. Straps ran from the top of the slide and were staked to the ground as well. The slide is 25' long, 12' wide and 22' tall.  Idaho doesn't regulate the safety of amusement devices, so this report was based on paramedic's report and CPSC research.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

acc_desc: A patron's foot had caught one of the deck plates which caused the plate to lift out of position. This led to additional 3 injuries suffered by patrons that were riding the attraction. Owner/operator made physical changes to the floor plates and the way they were fasted to the structure. Physical adjustments were made to the safety system that controlled the operational sequencing for the ride operation.

acc_desc: An 18' inflatable waterslide was dropped off at a private event. The rental company set it up, but did not provide an attendant. They tethered it with 100 lbs of sand on each side and stake the high level and corner tethers. The slide tipped over. At the time of the accident, 4-5 people were on top. The manual states only one person should be on top at a time. Investigators attributed the accident to: (1) no attendant on duty, (2) slide was overloaded, and (3) slide may have collapsed.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: The main axle on the wheel broke during use, which caused the ride to jolt and shift. The operator immediately shut down the wheel and passengers unloaded without any injuries. Several years prior to this incident, the manufacturer recommended that the main axle be retrofitted with a replacement that is significantly thicker. While the upgrade was recommended, it was not required. This owner/operator elected instead to install a safety cable through the axle in the event of failure, a less expensive option. The operators reportedly had a safety cable installed in the axle per the manufacturer's recommendations, in lieu of a retrofitted axle.

acc_desc: 22 children and one adult were riding when they heard a loud bang and the ride stopped suddenly. Inertia caused the swings to continue forward and the riders struck the back of the seats in front of them. The swings then swung backwards and sideways. The riders continued to strike each other and parts of the ride. Investigators found that the ride's hydraulic motor shaft broke and jammed in the ride.
injury_desc: 12 patrons were transported to the hospital. Most injuries were minor. One 8yo received laceration injuries to both shins, requiring surgery. Another child had a hairline fracture of her ankle.

acc_desc: Due to an upset child being allowed to exit, the ride operator was permitted to halt the ride. Before the ride started, the patrons' safety restraints were rechecked. At this time, the guest was holding onto the belt buckle and was told not to unbuckle because they were going to get going in just a second. After a final check of the restraints, the ride was scanned one last time before restarting. A moment later, the guest jumped from the ride vehicle and landed face down on the concrete. The e-stop button was pressed immediately and the exit gate unlocked to allow the mother to attend to the child.
injury_desc: Injuries not visible to ride operator. No follow-up with family was mentioned in report.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: The ride had finished its cycle and was stopped to allow unload patrons. As an attendant was assisting a family out of one of the ride's two cars, the operator decided to step out of the control booth. On his way out, he accidentally bumped into the control panel and the ride jolted into motion. Although the ride had an e-stop button, he panicked and began turning other switches. This resulted in an acceleration of the ride before it came to a stop. When the ride accelerated, the attendant was struck and injured by the moving car and the family, who had already removed their restraints, fell to the ride's metal platform. Some were also struck by the car after they ejected. Investigators determined that the ride had originally been designed so that it was inoperable when restraints were unlatched, but that feature had been malfunctioning and so the owner ordered the operator to bypass the control system using a wire jumper. The owner was arrested and charged with assault.
injury_desc: 5 people were hospitalized (4 patrons and one attendant) with injuries to brain, skull, neck, and spine.

acc_desc: Ride started up again as patrons were attempting to unload, resulting in serious injuries to the ride operator and 4 patrons, including one child. Investigators found that the ride owner, Joshua Macaroni, and a ride operator had jumpered the wiring to disable a safety system that would have prevented the ride from moving while the restraints were up. Macaroni and Family Attractions were fined more than $100,000. Macaroni and the ride operator were charged with assault with a deadly weapon.
injury_desc: 5 people were injured, 3 were admitted to the hospital, 2 in critical condition. One man suffered brain, skull, neck and spinal cord injuries; he was comatose for several months, is now blind and suffers from seizures.

The operator of the Gyroscope buckled the riders in the seats and pulled down the chest and lap bar protector. During the ride of a minute or so, patron told the operator that she was getting sick and that her seat belt had come loose. The operator stopped the ride as quick as possible and removed the two passengers. Patron said that she had hit her head on the ride 2 or 3 times and that she was sick on her stomach. Inspector found seatbelt to malfunction when locking. If plastic cover is in the right position, the locking component will not lock due to to cover interference.

source: West Virginia Division of Labor, Safety Section
acc_desc: Patron landed on her neck while attempting a forward flip. She was on the device with 2 adult friends. They exceeded the allowable height for the device (60"), but did not exceed the cumulative or individual weight limit.  They had been allowed to do flips for five minutes prior to the injury, in violation of the manufacturer's signage on front of the ride. Patron said she hadn't noticed the signs and didn't read the waiver she signed. The operator was not supervising the ride at the time of the accident. He was in a "roaming position", responsible for 3 units. This violated the park's SOP and West Virginia's rules. Investigators found a kink in the blower tube and instructed the park to move the unit, but they could not determine whether this contributed to the accident.
injury_desc: Compression fracture of the thorasic spine and herniated cervical disk requiring surgery

source: Wisconsin Dept. of Commerce, Safety and Building Division
acc_desc: Patron was ejected from the ride and struck 3 metal poles before landing face-first on the concrete 17 feet below. State inspectors found that the lap bar would not lock in place due to defective/worn mechanism. When examining the other restraints on the coaster, 11 of the 24 pawls skipped, resulting in 4 total lap bar failures. The owner/operator had not addressed a 4-year-old safety bulletin from the manufacturer, and failed to detect the worn restraints during in-house inspections. Weight restriction for passengers is 660lbs total for car. Combined patron weight in the car at time of ejection was 720 lbs.
injury_desc: Traumatic brain injury, broken neck, broken back, broken ribs and toes.  Spent 3 weeks in a coma.

acc_desc: During the ride, the bonnet on one of the tubs broke free of its mounting while the ride was in operation. The metal frame came down and hit the male rider on the left arm and the female rider on the back of the head. Upon inspection, state regulators discovered that several of the bonnet hooks had deteriorated and were severely corroded. It was also evident that some were in new condition and had recently been replaced. The owner was asked to make repairs to the corroded bonnet hooks.

acc_desc: 17 5th-graders were evaluated for injuries after an unanchored 18' tall inflatable slide tipped over, causing the children to fall to the gymnasium floor below the slide.  The rental company set up the slide and then left. The slide was not secured or anchored.

Investigators identified numerous operational discrepencies (i.e., failure to adhere to manufacturer's instructions).

acc_desc: A 22'-tall inflatable slide suddenly took flight when a gust of wind estimated at 30mph lifted the slide and tumbled it about 300 feet across a park field.  The slide, according to the owner, was staked down with 8 large stakes, four on each side.  Stakes were 42" x 1". Owner says they're typically driven in about 50% of stake length, and that the 42" stakes were purchased aftermarket because the stakes provided with the device were too small, in his opinion. Two children were on the slide at the time that it took flight.
injury_desc: One child suffered minor injuries and was taken to the hospital.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: 4yo male was plyaing at an inflatable play ground area when his mother couldn't find him. A staff member found him unresponsive in an inflatable play structure with a nylon tie-down strap wrapped around his neck. The boy was admitted to the hospital and died 7 days later. The owner/operator stated that the strap involved in the incident was attached to the top of the inflatable structure and intended to be used as a tie-down for outdoor use. When used indoors, the straps are typically placed on top of the inflatable where they are out of the way. The rep couldn't explain why the strap had fallen within reach of the child. He noted that the inflatable involved was not one of the usual structures in use at the FCC; some of the regular inflatables had been moved for use in an outdoor festival.

acc_desc: Patron was going down slide and hit the bottom when her husband came out the bottom and collided with her. She felt something pop. Her husband said he tried to stop himself from running into her, but couldn't. Investigators did not have enough information to determine what caused the accident. The park said they were considering a light system that would require the operator at bottom to signal the operator at the top when each rider cleared the slide. The investigator suggested they install a video system instead.

source: California Division of Occupational Safety and Health
acc_desc: 8-yo boy mistook a staging stop for the final stop and started to exit the car.  When the vehicle starting up again, his foot was crushed and caught between the side of the car and the unload platform.  DOSH found that five other children, ages 5-8 had suffered foot entrapment accidents on the ride since its opening a year prior.  In response to the earlier accidents, the park decided to modify the ride, reducing the gap from 50mm to 8mm in the hopes of eliminating the entrapment hazard.  Instead, the smaller gap increased the magnitude of injury. DOSH ordered the park to make a number of changes, including widening the gap back to 50mm+ and adding sensors that will perform a station stop if they detect something entering the gap.
injury_desc: Degloving of skin on top of foot, torn tendons and fractures requiring in-patient hospitalization, skin grafts, and physical therapy.

source: New Jersey Dept. of Community Affairs
acc_desc: After two guests and their equipment were removed from the cables on Zipline 2, flyer's left and right.  Guide proceeded finish the clearing and resetting procedures for the next two guests.  He opened the ropeclutch on flyer's left to decompress the springs, pulled the springs to position and closed the rope clutch.  Then he repeated those steps for flyer's right.  He then walked to the end of the spring bank to do a visual check and saw that the intake ropes on flyers left were tangled.  He untangled the rope, finished his visual check and signaled to the other guide that both flyer's left and right were clear and ready for the next guests,  He did not reopen the rope cllutch to decompress the springs farther, thus leaving a small sag in the rope.  When another patron impacted the spring bank on flyer's left the intake rope was stuck between the catch block and her trolley preventing the springs from compressing.  The usual movement and bounce of the cable must have caused the sagging rope to become caught in the catch block tooth.  Patron on flyer's right impacted the spring bank as normal.  Guide removed both guests from their trolley's and removed their trolleys from the lines.

Guest rode the rest of the slide down and was able to exit the splash pool on her own.  Emt arrived on scene and noticed apparent deformity and discoloration observed on right shoulder.  Ice pack issued and Ems called

acc_desc: A man was riding in the front of the train. The front coaches have an arm bar in front to hold onto. At some point during the ride, the door came unlatched and swung open, hitting the fencing or pole, then popped back and hit the man in the arm. Park stated that the front arm bar, when pushed on, will unlatch the doors of the train. It is spring loaded and is a fluke they noticed when the accident occurred. They will modify the ride to correct this.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: An inflatable slide went airborne after being swept up by a strong gust of wind (possibly a dust devil). The inflatable was setup in a public parking lot on an asphalt surface, anchored to a motor home and 3-4 55 gallon water drums using the manufacturer's tethers. The device was not in operation at the time of the accident and no injuries occurred.  The wind knocked over other objects as well (speaker poles, tents, awnings, etc.). It was so strong, it snapped the tethers.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Two teenagers were thrown from their carrier. As the gondola was coming down, the door opened and a 13yo boy was thrown into a barricade. The other rider, a 13yo girl fell from the gondola when it was at its maximum height, hitting the pavement near the ride's support legs. A patron waiting in line stated that the two operators were arguing when the teens boarded, and the operator in charge of directing patrons in did not close the door of their gondola. The witness yelled to the operators, but they started the ride anyway. Other witnesses corroborated that story. Texas does not have a regulatory unit to investigate accidents. By the time CPSC initiated an investigation, the ride had been moved and the owner/operator did not respond to CPSC.
injury_desc: 13yo female sustained serious head and facial injuries and was hospitalized for a week. 13yo male sustained minor injuries.

acc_desc: Struck by fellow rider in the same tube.

injury_desc: Two 13yo patrons were transported to hospital. Injuries not described.

Patron fell off the trampoline. She was wearing blue harness #72 and weighed 140 lbs. Operator stated he used 1-black bungee and 3-yellow bungees. Yellows are rated to hold 40 lbs, black are rated for 20 lbs.  After stating that the ride was ending and giving her one last bounce, a cable snapped as she was coming down. She fell from about 6' off the trampoline onto her feet and then her back and head. Damaged cable was not noticed during daily inspection. Training and inspection records were incomplete.
injury_desc: Injuries to feet/ankles, back and head. Patron transported to hospital.

The two vehicles struck each other and became stuck in Brake Three. At that time, the park manager called 911. The fire department evacuated four patrons from the loaded car without incident.

source: California Division of Occupational Safety and Health
acc_desc: State officials inspected the wheel after an incident where 45 patrons were evacuated. The wheel went down at 4:03, evacuation completed at 5:45. The e-stop is activated during each load/unload for each set of 3 gondolas, and there are 24 gondolas. The e-stop is not a power disconnect. After several attempts to reset the ride, a determination was made to evacuate patrons by manually rotating the ride. Hydraulic tensioners were released puling drive tires 1 and 4 away from the wheel drive rim. Hydraulic tensioners for Drives 2 and 3 were manually operated to provide braking as the wheel was manually pulled into position for unloading each set of 3 gondolas.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Two children, ages 2 and 3 were injured (one critically) when the inflatable bounce house they were playing in unexpectedly went airborne in a wind gust of approximately 11mph. The inflatable flew 30 feet vertically and 50 feet horizontally before crashing to the ground with the boys inside. They were trapped under the deflated house and bystanders had to cut them out. Initial investigation revealed that the inflatable was not open to the public at time of incident and was not staked down, but rather was set up (unsupervised) to dry out after having gotten wet from rain the day before.
injury_desc: 2yo airlifted to an out-of-state hospital; 3yo transported to local hospital.
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

acc_desc: Two boys (2yo & 3yo) entered unattended bounce house that was inflated to dry, but was not anchored.  Wind picked it up and 2 children were seriously injured.
injury_desc: One child air lifted to hospital other child brought to local hospital.  Injuries unknown
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

acc_desc: Patron came down a slide and turned her ankle at the slide landing.  EMS reported accident to the state at 10:48pm.

A guest (first responder) assisted the child in freeing his foot and controlled the bleeding until park EMS arrived.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: A water spout came ashore and lifted an inflatable obstacle course 15-20 feet in the air, carrying it across the roadway where it landed. Three children were thrown from the device and suffered minor injuries. There was also a report of a ride operator being knocked down, but he was not injured. The device consisted of 3 separate parts connected with Velcro. It was set up on an asphalt basketball court, anchored to a concrete hoop with a length of rope and weighted down with sand bags on the corners. Although windspeed was not measured for this particular waterspout, they typically range 50-80 mph.
injury_desc: Laceration to upper lip (5yo); Laceration to mouth (11yo); abdominal pain (6yo)
category: Device tipped over, blew away, or collapsed

source: Michigan Dept. of Labor and Economic Growth
acc_desc: Accident happened on the first lap of the first driving session for this group. Patron failed to brake when approaching the end of the straightaway and turn 4, collided with the barrier, and spun 180 degrees with the front of the kart several inches off the ground.  Another driver following closely also failed to brake and collided with the first vehicle. One kart landed on top of the other.
injury_desc: Visible injury to skee area; transported by paramedics to hospital

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Participants jump from one of three tiers (platform levels) in a scaffolding type structure onto an air bag. Patrons are instructed to run out as far as they can, kick their feet out and land on their butt on the air bag. Patron went up to the top tier (36' above ground), then hesitated. Jump master suggested she go to the 2nd level (26'). As she started to walk off the platform, she used her left hand to grap the side rail on the scaffolding. This caused her to hit the scaffolding and fall straight down, hitting the edge of the air bag pillow (rather than the center as intended). There is a gap between the air bag pillow and scaffolding of approx. 18 inches. Video of the event shows several patrons jumping from different levels during the time the victim was considering her jump, as well as people below taunting her.
Prior surgery, otherwise unknown

acc_desc: Train derailed with six passengers on board (3 children).  All were seated to the inside. Some or all of the patrons fell out when the train tipped over. Inspectors found that over 50% of the track had fill washed away from rains the previous month. State inspectors ordered the company to train staff on proper inspection and ensure that inspections occur each day.

Report states the park cleaned up the accident scene before calling state regulators.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: 3 children (ages 6, 6, 5) sustained minor injuries when a metal hitch connecting two roller coaster cars failed. The rear four cars derailed and stopped abruptly. The failed hitch was not original to the ride and the manufacturer deemed the incident weld insufficient. Witnesses reported seeing carnival staff hitting the incident track with sledgehammers to straighten it out prior to the incident. State officials believe the insufficient weld along with the misaligned track caused the incident. A news article stated that the ride supervisor was charged with falsifying physical evidence.
injury_desc: Bloody nose, bleeding gums, contusions to head. At least one child was transported to the hospital.

acc_desc: Adult woman fell off the ride during operation. First responders estimated her weight to be 325 lbs. Their report stated that she did not secure the horizontal restraint bar in front of her waist because her size would not permit the bar to lower.The victim slipped out of her set and fell to the ground, landed on her shoulder and rolled 1/2 turn onto her back. The state fire marshall stated that she shouldn't have been allowed on the ride because of her age and size, as it is intended for children, and attributed the accident to operator error.

acc_desc: Operator ran the ride for a full cycle. When she stopped the ride, the momentum carried the cars past the load/unload station. She announced to patrons "we are going around one more time" and started the ride.  An 18-month-old rider was standing up when the ride started again. She fell out of the car and her foot got stuck, causing her to hand upside down and strike her head on the track stand.  State investigators questioned whether the ride does or should have a minimum height restriction to prevent 18mo toddlers from riding alone.

source: Wisconsin Dept. of Commerce, Safety and Building Division
acc_desc: The pins holding the footwell onto the tub came loose, the footwell slid off the tub, and the footwell came into contact with the sweep causing the sweep to come to an abrupt stop. Several tests were conducted to determine the cause of the incident and injuries. After observation, investigation, and inspection it was confIrmed that the footwell had come loose and struck the sweep. The pins/clasps holding the footwells to the seat rattled loose which indicates they were either installed incorrectly or worn to a point where they would no longer hold. It was also determined that the operator of the ride who conducted a documented pre-operational check of the ride had no written documentation of training.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Restraint came open during ride, causing 13yo girl to fall out of her seat and tumble around inside the cage as the ride spun. A law enforcement official patrolling the carnival looked up and saw the situation and ordered the operator to stop the ride. Upon inspection, the law enforcement officer saw that the buckle was not connected to the restraint bar. The ride experienced a mechanical failure of the air compression system that kept the pull-down shoulder bar in place. Law enforcement investigation identified several additional incidents involving harness failures on the same ride, as well as incidents on other rides during the carnival. Investigators located a service bulletin from the manufacturer instructing owner/operators to replace all shoulder restraints older than 5 years due to corrosion.
injury_desc: Scratches and bruises to left shoulder, pulled muscle in left leg while attempting to brace herself.
category: Fall: patron fell from seat, but not carrier

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: 16yo girl died when she fell out of a giant 3-person swing. Investigators concluded that the ride's operator failed to fasten the victim's safety harness to the swing prior to launch.  The ride was short-staffed at the time of the accident; the assistant operator left due to illness.  The victim was videotaping her ride; review of the video after the accident showed that she was not attached to the apparatus when the swing retracted from the platform.
injury_desc: Death from blunt force trauma to neck

acc_desc: Patron bumped the back of his head on the ride. He went on his own to first aid, then went to the hospital.

acc_desc: Patron and another kid were bouncing in the device and one kid fell onto the other, causing him to land on his arm.

The race had finished and the karts were entering the pit area. Patron got his kart stuck while entering the pit lane to park. Another kart came up behind him, failed to trake and ran directly in the patron's kart from behind.

Woman and child were getting off of ride and woman took a step while she was holding child's hand and tripped over her own feet and fell with child, pulling him down. We had already stopped ride and helped her up.

Mother and two children were loaded into required area. As cart comes to injured party and children, employee A loads the child on the inside of cart instead of children on the outside. As cart continues to move, child on the inside has been loaded but child on outside is still not loaded. It is at this time that employee A places child in cart, hitting injured party in the nose, possibly breaking it.
walking caring child

acc_desc: Was jumping and landed wrong on his left arm.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: While loading, two passengers fell from their seat and landed on the ride operator. The operator had loaded 6 people in accordance with the ride's load balancing requirments. The incident occurred when he began to load a 28yo woman and her 8yo daughter. As both victims climbed into the car, but with the door not yet secured, their carrier suddenly shifted upwards about 8-10 feet. The ride operator tried to quickly lower the car, but the victims fell out when the car flipped downward and the door flopped open. The operator caught the girl, the mom fell on top of them, then the operator was struck in the back by another moving carrier. The three victims were transported to a nearby hospital with minor injuries. The incident was caused by a brake failure on one of the cable drive motors. State investigators indicated that improper tire pressure, moisture from dew and the interface between the tires and driven rims may have contributed, but the failure appeared to be a maintenance-related issue.

acc_desc: A woman's scarf became entangled in the go-kart wheel as she was riding on the track along with her husband, children and mother. Operators allowed the woman and her mother to ride while wearing scarves. The woman's windpipe was severed during the accident. Go-kart tracks are regulated by the State Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs, but that regulation is limited to approving the construction and engineering of the track and there is no real oversight or tracking of safety.
injury_desc: Severed windpipe. The woman remains in a permanent vegetative state.
notes: Accident not included in records provided by the state. https://www.woodtv.com/news/grand-rapids/family-of-woman-severely-injured-in-go-kart-crash-seek-changes/1389160764

acc_desc: While the ride was oscillating back and forth, a nut and bolt fell off the ride. The ride operator heard them hit the metal platform and eased up on the controls, causing the ride to slow down faster. Once the ride had stopped, the ride operator assisted the 4 people off the ride and closed it down for inspection. The bolt and nut were later re-attached and the other five similar bolts and nuts were checked and found to be securely wrenched down.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Three girls boarded a car on the Sizzler, which had lap bars and lap belts. The girls' lap belt wouldn't latch as it was too short. The surviving girls stated that the operator told them they could ride without it, using just the lap bar. The operator disputes this, but said that he did not physically check to make sure the lap bar was latched because he didn't feel comfortable placing his hands in/near the laps of teenage girls. Two of the girls were ejected when the ride sped up. Both the operator and the surviving girls stated that the ride was going very fast. The company operating the ride didn't own it; they were using another company's ride, having traded for the day.  The carnival owner, who was not operating the ride stated that he saw a girl standing on her seat prior to being ejected; the ride operator did not corroborate that story.  Texas does not have a regulatory unit to investigate accidents. CPSC's report states that they were able to inspect the ride, but the results were not included in this report (referenced case #160502CFE0003).
injury_desc: 16yo female (60", 119lbs) died from blunt force injury to the head; 17yo female was taken by ambulance to the hospital for unspecified injuries; 17yo female who wasn't ejected sustained a large bruise to right knee and hip

acc_desc: Two patrons were ejected from the ride. CPSC report states that the seat belt was too short to latch across the three riders.
injury_desc: 16yo girl was killed, 15yo girl was injured

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Four children (ages 4-10), an adult male patron, and the ride operator received minor electrical shocks while exiting the metal cars of a stationary amusement ride located in an ocean-front park. A 10yo and the adult male received more significant shocks when the grabbed onto metal fencing surrounding the ride. The most likely cause of the incident was determined to be internal wiring for the flourescent lighting, which shorted out when a foreign peice of metal fell onto the electric ring assembly of the rotating base of the ride, making a connection between the rings.
injury_desc: Electrical shock, burns to palm of hands. Treated and released at a local hospital.

13yo boy diagnosed with concussion following school trip to the park.  He stated he rode this coaster and in the section where the up-and-down hills are, it felt like the track was rippled, that the seat was lifting off the track. He felt his body lifted and his head lifted several times, then everything seemed to crash down. He bit his tongue.  Upon exiting, he felt unsteady with pressure in his head. He did not report symptoms until he was at home with his mother.

acc_desc: A front passenger of a double ride sled was ejected from the ride. The couple was coming in at full speed into the flags area. A repeater, which triggers automatically played the safety spiel to slow down, was ignored by the man in the back, who controlled the brakes. It is believed that the woman in front, who was ejected, was not buckled in and her restraint was not checked prior to launch.
injury_desc: Multiple fractures on both wrists, knee caps, and left elbow.  Trauma to the head including left eye. Possible broken ribs.

After conclusion of a normal operation cycle, the tower 1 lift wire rope (cable) detached from the up side of the winch drum clamping plate. The weight of the cable caused the cable to pull through the upper sheave on twoer 1 (approx. 100 ft high) and pile up at the base of the tower. At the time of the incident, all but 2 patrons had cleared the station platform and the remaining two were seated in the trian preparing to disembark. No injuries reported.

Park disputes her story, says that their party arrived at the park 30 minutes after this pool was closed.

notes: CPSC requested NDT records from the owner/operator, but ride owner did not respond.

injury_desc: 10yo boy was killed.  Two other riders were injured (broken jaw, facial fractures, eye damage).

acc_desc: 3 girls (6, 10 and 16) fell 40 feet from one of the gondolas on a Ferris wheel. Car number 9 got caught on a bar and caused car to overturn. injury_desc: 6yo: traumatic brain injury, critical condition; 10yo: broken arm, hospitalized; 16yo: hospitalized in critical condition.

acc_desc: 3yo boy fell from the ride. (Remaining details are from news reports) - According to police sources, the child was riding with his 7yo brother, when he was ejected on the last turn of the ride, falling from a height of around 12 feet and landing on the tracks near a fence. The coaster was built in 1938 and does not have seat belts. Passengers must be 48 inches tall to ride alone or 36 inches tall to ride with an adult.
injury_desc: Head injury. Child was airlifted to the hospital and admitted in critical condition.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: Twelve patrons, ages 11-18, were injured when the ride's safety lap bars opened while the ride was in operation. Investigators found that the ride operator was in the process of switching the ride from auto to manual mode when he turned the open lap bar switch, causing them to open while the ride was in mid-air. Several victims fell from their seats ont the ride's flooring. After the incident, the ride was reprogrammed so that all safeties are in effect whether in Automatic or Manual mode and the ride is level with the deck.
injury_desc: Fractures, neck strain, back injuries and emotional distress.
category: Fall: patron fell from seat, but not carrier

acc_desc: Dispatcher error

acc_desc: While the ride was in operation with guests on it, the computer operating system detected a fault, put the ride into safe mode and started to bring it down. The ride operator panicked and hit the manual override release button for the safety bars, which caused patrons to fall from their seats. 6 children and 2 adults were transported to hospital.
injury_desc: Complaints of ankle, wrist, head and neck injuries, including leg fracture, arm fracture, collarbone fracture.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: The electrical inflatable blower motor for an inflatable obstacle course located in an indoor fun center was observed by a parent to be smoking. The blower motor caught fire and caused heat and smoke/soot damage to the facility. No one was injured in the incident, but there was approximately $200,000 in damages to the structure and $250,000 in damage to the contents. The device was a 1 horsepower blower that plugged into a standard 110V outlet. The blower (In-Flate ETL, Model IF-1 blower distributed with the Batman inflatable) caught fire prior to the employee turning off the power. The fire extended to the Batman inflatable before the sprinkler system activated. The fire dept. arrived and extinguished the fire.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: A 13yo boy and 10yo girl were riding, and had reached an approximate height of 15-20 feet, when the door came open and boy's restraint bar released. The boy fell from the ride, but caught himself by grabbing the restraint bar. The girl was held by her restraint bar and the boy was able to prevent himself from falling until they were rescued. Amusement ride inspectors from the state who investigated the incident believe operator error caused the door to come open, when the operator failed to ensure and double-check that the over-the-shoulder restraint bar latch and door latches properly engaged. They also report that "the harness was not latching properly due to a design flaw that was confirmed by the manufacturer, related to a retrofit that modified the restraint/door system.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: At least one patron suffered crushing injuries to feet/legs when a sweep dropped to the ground and at least one carrier struck part of the structure. Preliminary inspection by state authorities indicates that a 3" diameter locking nut bearing assembly came loose or broke, allowing the sweep to drop to the ground. Threads appeared severely corroded and misalligned threads connected to the vertical support shaft.
injury_desc: 20yo male was airlifted to the hospital with serious crush injuries to feet/legs. State ride inspector said he knew of six others who were treated and released on site, and mentioned unverified reports of 15 other injured persons.
category: Impact: extremity hit something outside carrier

acc_desc: Patron landed wrong on the trampoline bed.

acc_desc: While train was returning toward the train station, the rear wheels of the caboose derailed. As the train continued down a slope, the back wheels tailed to the north and ultimately the caboose turned onto its side. Three patrons were injured. The caboose was removed from the site before state authorities were notifies, so it could not be inspected. The owner/operator states that the rail was inspected and no cause for the derailment could be found.
injury_desc: (1) Fractured tailbone and sprained knee; (2) Headache, knee and hip; (3) Minor cuts on elbow

acc_desc: A patron with a pre-existing condition fainted after riding. EMTs took over after they arrived and the patron was transported. The owner/operator believes the patron subsequently passed away.

acc_desc: Three people (47yo female, 59yo female, 7yo male) fell 30 feet from their carrier. Police were told the ride made a grinding sound and something appeared to fall out. The cart slowly tipped over and dumped the passengers. The carnival purchased the ride without restraints and was told that the manufacturer would void the warrenty if seatbelts were added.
injury_desc: The 59yo was airlifted in critical condition with a head injury and multiple fractures. The other two were transported to a nearby hospital.

acc_desc: While driving one of the go-karts, and wearing a hair tie, a woman's hair got tangled in the axle. Crews say they had to cut apart the go-kart to free her. That woman, who is from New York, was flown to the hospital.
injury_desc: Patron's hair and scalp were ripped off, leaving her skull exposed. Multiple surgeries were required to try to reshape her head. It's not yet known whether all the hair will regrow.

source: United States Consumer Product Safety Commission
acc_desc: One of the 4-person gondolas of a high g-force ride suddenly detached from the main part of the ride, went airborne and finally landed on the ground approximately one foot from the base of the ride. Cause was determined to be excessive corrosion. The ride passed state inspection shortly before the accident.
injury_desc: 18yo male was killed. 7 other riders were transported to the hospital, some with critical injuries.
